Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A carpenter is waiting for you to bring them the next load of lumber so they can continue their work without interruption.
Story: I was halfway down the apartment hallway, leash in hand, when my dog started barking at the sound of footsteps near the shared door. Mrs. Lee from next door shot me a look—her usual silent plea for peace and quiet. I tried to hush my dog, feeling the weight of her expectation that I keep the hallway calm and respectful for everyone. But my phone buzzed in my pocket: a text from the site foreman. The carpenter needed the next load of lumber, and I was already running behind. If I didn’t get back soon, the whole crew would be waiting, and I’d be letting them down. My mind raced, torn between calming my dog to keep the peace with my neighbor and sprinting back to the site to keep the job moving. I could feel the pressure from both sides, each demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time. My heart pounded as I stood frozen in the hallway, caught between the expectations of home and work, not sure which way to turn.
